Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Yell \Yell\, n. A sharp, loud, hideous outcry. [1913 Webster]
Their hideous yells Rend the dark welkin. --J. Philips. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Yell \Yell\ (y[e^]l), v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Yelled}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Yelling}.] [OE. yellen, [yogh]ellen, AS. giellan, gillan, gyllan; akin to D. gillen, OHG. gellan, G. gellen, Icel. gjalla, Sw. g["a]lla to ring, resound, and to AS., OS., & OHG. galan to sing, Icel. gala. Cf. 1st {Gale}, and {Nightingale}.] To cry out, or shriek, with a hideous noise; to cry or scream as with agony or horror. [1913 Webster]
They yelleden as feendes doon in helle. --Chaucer. [1913 Webster]
Nor the night raven, that still deadly yells. --Spenser. [1913 Webster]
Infernal ghosts and hellish furies round Environed thee; some howled, some yelled. --Milton. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Yell \Yell\, v. t. To utter or declare with a yell; to proclaim in a loud tone. --Shak. [1913 Webster]

yell n 1: a loud utterance; often in protest or opposition; "the speaker was interrupted by loud cries from the rear of the audience" [syn: {cry}, {outcry}, {call}, {shout}, {vociferation}] 2: a loud utterance of emotion (especially when inarticulate); "a cry of rage"; "a yell of pain" [syn: {cry}] v 1: utter a sudden loud cry; "she cried with pain when the doctor inserted the needle"; "I yelled to her from the window but she couldn't hear me" [syn: {shout}, {shout out}, {cry}, {call}, {scream}, {holler}, {hollo}, {squall}] 2: utter or declare in a very loud voice; "You don't have to yell--I can hear you just fine" [syn: {scream}]
